channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Israel-Gaza: Rockets hit Israel after militants killed
item.description: Palestinian militants fire a barrage of rockets after some of their commanders die in air strikes.

item.title: The NHS Covid legacy - long waits and lives at risk
item.description: One in four hospitals sees long waits balloon, as NHS warned backlog will take years to tackle.

item.title: Crime drops by 8% during year of lockdowns, says ONS
item.description: A 26% fall in theft offences drove a reduction in crime recorded by police in England and Wales.

item.title: Travel firms warned over summer holiday refunds
item.description: Companies will be breaking the law if they delay or refuse refunds, warns the competition watchdog.

item.title: Universal credit fraud and error at new high
item.description: Figures from the Department for Work and Pensions show £8.4bn was lost in 2020-21.

item.title: Premier League TV rights: Broadcasters agree to roll over existing deal
item.description: The Premier League agrees to roll over its existing television deal with broadcasters for a further three years.

item.title: Boris Johnson's lawyers confident of cancelling court judgement
item.description: A county-court order against the PM for a debt of £535 was over a claim of defamation, it has emerged.

item.title: Labour MP quits front bench over interfering in sexual harassment case
item.description: Labour's Kate Hollern was accused of trying to "scare" Tory MP Andrew Bridgen away from helping complainant.

item.title: Tesla will no longer accept Bitcoin over climate concerns, says Musk
item.description: The initial decision made by Tesla in March to accept Bitcoin caused an outcry from environmentalists.

item.title: MDMA could help trauma survivors face painful memories
item.description: Usually thought of as a party drug, a trial suggests it helps people with post-traumatic stress disorder.

item.title: St Paul's Cathedral could close without tourism cash
item.description: The world-famous cathedral has seen its finances devastated by the pandemic.

item.title: HS2 high-speed rail project begins underground tunnel
item.description: At 170m long, "Florence" is the largest ever tunnelling machine to be used on a UK rail project.

item.title: The papers: Fears of 'all-out war' and concerns over variant
item.description: Pictures of destruction in Gaza and Israel feature on the front pages of several papers.

item.title: Covid: The race to vaccinate the world
item.description: What happens when vaccines are slow to arrive - and what it means for ending lockdowns.

item.title: How viral pianist with dementia is helping others
item.description: When Paul Harvey's piano playing went viral, it inspired a donation of £1 million to charity.

item.title: Falkland Islands: Veterans reunite after almost 40 years
item.description: Navy veteran David reaches out to other survivors of an event that killed 12 crew members.

item.title: The plasterer redecorating domestic violence survivors' homes
item.description: Naima-Ben Moussa, who offers her services for free, believes more needs to be done to support victims.

item.title: Ruthie Henshall: Lack of visits 'took her down so quickly' in care home
item.description: The actress pays tribute to her mother Gloria, who died in a care home on Tuesday.

item.title: Facebook moderator: ‘Every day was a nightmare’
item.description: This is the first time a social media moderator has testified to a parliamentary committee.

item.title: Gemma Arterton: Screen and stage star excited at theatres reopening
item.description: The actress will soon be back on stage in London as theatres reopen with lockdown restrictions easing.

item.title: Ellen DeGeneres to end talk show after 19 years
item.description: "As great as this show is, and as fun as it is, it's just not a challenge any more," she explains.

item.title: Arthur Beale: Sailing goods business closes shop after 500 years
item.description: The Arthur Beale store, which sells specialist marine supplies, says the pandemic has forced its closure.

item.title: In pictures: Commons marks 80 years since WW2 bombing
item.description: Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle commemorates those who died when a Luftwaffe attack destroyed the Commons chamber.

item.title: Eid: 'You can be Muslim and still enjoy playing football'
item.description: For young Muslim footballers like Omar and Rahma, it's vital that faith and football go together.

item.title: Queen's Speech debate: Waiting lists, social care and other claims fact-checked
item.description: Politicians debated the government's plans - set out in the Queen's Speech - and made a series of claims on subjects including hospital waiting lists and social care.

item.title: Lampedusa: Italy's gateway to Europe struggles with migrant influx
item.description: Italy appeals for EU help as 2,000 arrivals within days fill Lampedusa's migrant camp.

item.title: 'Cocaine of the sea' threatens critically endangered vaquita
item.description: The vaquita marina in Mexico is threatened by a clash of interests between fishing and conservation.

item.title: I love being a mogul: The Hollywood stars going into business
item.description: With the pandemic shutting down Hollywood over the past year, actors have been starting companies.

item.title: St Vincent: 'Without music, I'd be dead'
item.description: Inspired by her father's release from prison, St Vincent says her new album feels like a lifeline.

item.title: Tommy Mallet: 'I don't read emails longer than five words'
item.description: The Only Way Is Essex star Tommy Mallet opens up about the challenges he has faced with literacy and dyslexia.

item.title: Police expand use of overdose life-saver drug Naloxone
item.description: But officers' representatives are concerned the roles of police and paramedics are becoming blurred.

item.title: Israel-Gaza violence: The strength and limitations of Hamas' arsenal
item.description: The militant group possesses thousands of missiles of varying ranges that it can fire towards Israel.

item.title: Arteta says media 'try to put things on me I never said' in angry post-match interview
item.description: Arsenal boss Mikel Arteta says the media "try to put things on me I never said" after their 1-0 win over Chelsea.

item.title: 'When I was younger, I thought I had to try to do it all' - the cricketer combining cultural pressures with elite sport
item.description: Cricketer Naomi Dattani explains how professional contracts have helped her juggle cultural expectations with elite sport.

item.title: The British triathlete taking on the Brownlee brothers
item.description: Alex Yee is the Olympic hopeful who could deny Alastair Brownlee a shot at a third title at the Tokyo Games.

item.title: Match of the Day: Watch Ilkay Gundogan's best goals in Man City's title win
item.description: Match of the Day's Alan Shearer and Dion Dublin look back at some of Ilkay Gundogan's "wonderful" goals for title-winners Manchester City.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Period changes could be a short-term side effect
item.description: Stories of genuine experiences shared online have been followed by a wave of anti-vaccine disinformation.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What is a Covid passport and what are the plans for the NHS app?
item.description: People travelling abroad from England will be able to use the NHS app to prove their Covid vaccination status.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 38 and 39 in England are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the rollout continues.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: An independent public inquiry has been announced, but how will it work?

item.title: Restaurants and pubs are reopening inside, but what are the rules?
item.description: People in England, Scotland and Wales will soon be able to drink inside a pub.

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules and the rule of six?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family is being relaxed in England and Scotland from 17 May.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Lockdown restrictions will ease in England, Scotland and Wales from Monday 17 May.

item.title: Which countries are on the green list for foreign holidays?
item.description: Scotland is to adopt the same "traffic light" system for foreign travel as England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Secondary school pupils in England will no longer be required to wear them in class from next week.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the Covid-19 alert level system work?
item.description: The threat of Covid-19 in England is ranked through a five-level, colour-coded alert system.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 35 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays will be possible after 17 May, but what rights do you have if plans or rules change?

item.title: Chinese dreams on Native American land: A tale of cannabis boom and bust
item.description: How the pandemic cannabis boom led to chaos on the Navajo Nation, pitting two minorities against each other.

item.title: The 'smart and cheeky' Aboriginal boy teaching Australia a lesson
item.description: A film about an Aboriginal boy's experience of school shines a light on Australia's failure to give all children a fair start.

item.title: Joe Ligon: America's 'longest juvenile lifer' on 68 years in prison
item.description: After waiting seven decades for freedom, Joe Ligon tells the BBC how he intends to spend the rest of his days.

item.title: Lelush: How a sulky Russian model became China's slacker icon
item.description: Getting trapped in a boy band reality TV contest was just the start of Lelush's unlikely journey.

item.title: The young woman trying to adopt her friend
item.description: Arina hopes to formally adopt her friend Nina, whom she looked after during the Covid pandemic.
